title: AB 1534
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature emphasizes the importance of county assessors following state laws for consistent and accurate assessment practices. They aim to protect taxpayers by ensuring that decisions on property exemptions and ownership changes are made by certified staff. Implementation of education and certification requirements should be done efficiently with the advice of the State Board of Equalization. Section 674 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to require competitive bids for appraisal work contracts. Contractors must maintain confidentiality of assessee information as per specified sections. A contractor authorized by the assessor may request information from an assessee, but cannot share appraisal data with assessors from other counties. They must not retain confidential information after the contract ends and must return it within 90 days. After the conclusion of a contract, a contractor must purge and return any assessee records to the assessor within 90 days. The contract must include provisions to comply with these requirements as prescribed by the State Board of Equalization. All contracts must include provisions to comply with requirements set by the State Board of Equalization. A contractor is defined as any person not employed by the state, county, or city who performs appraisal work under contract with an assessor. Assessors or their employees must hold a valid assessment analyst certificate to make decisions on changes in ownership. Assessors or their employees must hold a valid assessment analyst certificate issued by the board to make decisions on changes in ownership and property tax exemptions, except for homeowners' exemption claims. The board requires applicants for an assessment analyst certificate to pass an examination to demonstrate competency in making change in ownership or exemption decisions. The examinations are prepared by the board with the assistance of a committee of assessors. Applicants denied a certificate have the right to a review according to the Administrative Procedure Act. Applicants denied a certificate have the right to a review under the Administrative Procedure Act. The board does not charge assessors or county employees with valid appraiser certificates for examinations or training. Certified assessment analysts must complete 24 hours of board-approved training annually to maintain their certificate, with excess hours carrying over for up to three years. The board requires certified assessment analysts to complete 24 hours of annual training, with excess hours carrying over for up to three years. Failure to comply may result in certificate revocation. Training covers new developments in case law, statutory law, and administrative rules. Advanced assessment analyst certification is available for those with three years of experience and meeting specific criteria. The board offers an advanced assessment analyst certificate for individuals with at least three years of experience who have completed advanced study or passed an advanced level examination. To maintain the certificate, holders must complete 12 hours of training annually. To maintain the advanced assessment analyst certificate, holders must complete 12 hours of training annually. Excess training hours can be carried over for up to two years. Failure to comply may result in certificate revocation, with training covering new legal developments. Training for the advanced assessment analyst certificate must cover new legal developments, including case law, statutory law, and administrative rules. Applicants must disclose financial interests in legal entities at certification and annually thereafter. Duplicate filings with the Fair Political Practices Commission may fulfill this requirement. The board may issue a temporary certificate to newly elected or appointed assessors or new employees in the county assessor's office for up to one year to allow them to take an examination for certification. Temporary certificates cannot be renewed unless the person is duly elected or appointed as assessor. The board may issue an interim certificate to current assessors or county assessor office employees for up to four years to allow them to apply for certification. Noncertificated staff can assist with exemption applications and ownership documents but cannot make decisions. This article applies in counties or cities that have passed a resolution upon the assessor's recommendation to require certification.
